messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "jewellgm" <greg17@...> wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@> wrote:
> >
> > jewellgm wrote:
> > > Hi All,
> > >
> > > I created a parameterized test using the pattern discussed in a
> recent
> > > thread. Now that I've got that up and running, I'd like to
> generate
> > > HTML reports of the results.
> > >
> > > However, since there are any typical "test" methods in the
class,
> > > the "junit" task in ant now fails.
> > >
> > > Is there an existing workaround/solution to this?
> >
> > Are you running the class that has the custom suite() method on
it?
> > <junit> should find those tests and run them instead of looking
for
> > test*() methods.
> >
> > Can you show us your Ant task and where it's failing?
> > --
>
>
> Thanks for the response -- I'm sorry that I've left out necessary
> information.
>
> I have a test class that reads from a configuration file. This
> configuration file contains the list of parameters that I want to
be
> used for the test suite. While I can hard code the name of the
file,
> I'd really like the user to be able to specify the file from the
> command line.
>
> Right now, I have an overloaded suite() method that takes a string -
-
> the name of the configuration file. That's why the junit task
can't
> find anything to run.
>
> I suppose that I could assign the file name to some environment
> variable and have the test class read that, but it's rather
kludgy.
> Is there an extension to the pattern that allows this configuration
> data from an outside source?
>
>
> Thanks again!
>


I'm afraid I probably just caused a bit more confusion. To clarify:
I am already able to specify the name of the configuration file from
the command line if I call the class directly. It's from within the
ant framework that I'm having these difficulties. I can use
the "java" task to execute the class, but then I don't get the XML
(and then HTML) reports. That is what is making me think the
environment variable may be the only way to go....
